image.altText: Soldiers in uniform stand near a tank in the streets of Rostov-on-Don

items.synopsis: The Wagner leader orders his mercenary forces to stop the march towards the capital after talks with Belarusian president and Putin ally Alexander Lukashenko.

title.children: Prigozhin orders end to Wagner's march on Moscow over risk of bloodshed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The success or failure of Prigozhin may largely depend on how many allies he has and if he can mobilise Russians to join him, says Russian expert and London's King's College academic Anna Matveeva. Ms Matveeva told Reuters ifPrigozhin manages to garner the backing of those "within the power and security structures" including police and military intelligence, the situation could descend into "a much wider crisis". "I think the development which we are to watch is to see whether Wagner and Prigozhin have any allies," she said. She added Wagner made up "a very good part of the Russian armed forces". "And certainly, they have been doing a heavy lift at the frontlines in the recent months. So yes, they are a force to be reckoned with."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wagner 'a force to be reckoned with', says expert

children.content: The success or failure of Prigozhin may largely depend on how many allies he has and if he can mobilise Russians to join him, says Russian expert and London's King's College academic Anna Matveeva.

Ms Matveeva told Reuters ifPrigozhin manages to garner the backing of those "within the power and security structures" including police and military intelligence, the situation could descend into "a much wider crisis".
"I think the development which we are to watch is to see whether Wagner and Prigozhin have any allies," she said.
She added Wagner made up "a very good part of the Russian armed forces".
"And certainly, they have been doing a heavy lift at the frontlines in the recent months. So yes, they are a force to be reckoned with."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wagner mercenaries have been promised an amnesty if they lay down their weapons but they need to act fast, state-owned Russian news agency TASS has cited a politician as saying. "Wagner fighters can still lay down their arms and avoid punishment given their achievements during the special military operation [in Ukraine], but they should do it fast," Pavel Krasheninnikov was quoted as saying. Krashennikov is a former Russian Justice Minister, and is now a Deputy of the State Duma, the lower house of Russia's Federal Assembly.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Russian media says Wagner fighters promised amnesty to disarm

children.content: Wagner mercenaries have been promised an amnesty if they lay down their weapons but they need to act fast, state-owned Russian news agency TASS has cited a politician as saying.

"Wagner fighters can still lay down their arms and avoid punishment given their achievements during the special military operation [in Ukraine], but they should do it fast," Pavel Krasheninnikov was quoted as saying.
Krashennikov is a former Russian Justice Minister, and is now a Deputy of the
, the lower house of Russia's Federal Assembly.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The governor of the Lipetsk region, north of Voronezh, has confirmed Wagner is moving through the area, according to BBC reports. Governor Igor Artamov earlier urged residents to stay indoors and "avoid travelling by any means". Lipetsk is less than 400km from Moscow .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wagner moving through area less than 400km from Moscow, says governor

children.content: , has confirmed Wagner is moving through the area, according to BBC reports.
Governor Igor Artamov earlier urged residents to stay indoors and "avoid travelling by any means".

props.alt: A map of Moscow with markers showing Moscow, Lipetsk, Voronezh and Rostov-on-Don

image.altText: Founder of Wagner private mercenary group Yevgeny Prigozhin in military gear.

items.synopsis: The Kremlin says Mr Prigozhin will move to Belarus under a deal brokered by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko to end the mutiny.

title.children: Prigozhin's Wagner fighters turn back from march on Moscow, Kremlin says mercenary boss will move to Belarus

image.altText: A close up of Yevgeny Prigozhin and Vladimir Putin.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision to launch a full-scale war against Ukraine has backfired catastrophically, so much so that it may end up leading to his downfall, writes Steve Cannane.

title.children: Putin has never looked so vulnerable, and it's due to his own creations

image.altText: A composite image of two Facebook ads, run by the Yes and No Voice campaigns.

items.synopsis: Both sides of the Voice to Parliament referendum campaign are starting to spend big on social media advertising, and where they’re directing their dollars gives us some clues about their strategies, writes Casey Briggs.

title.children: The Voice No campaign has spied a path to victory, and it hangs on Australia's smallest states

image.altText: Creamy coloured paste substance on a green peice of fabric layed out on a concrete floor with a girl standing next to it

items.synopsis: Follow the path cocaine takes from Colombian bush labs to your local suburbs — and the battle to intercept it.

title.children: How cocaine gets into Australia — and the battle to keep it out

image.altText: A portrait of Mandy looking into the camera. Her van is behind her. The back is open. Many items are inside.

items.synopsis: The rise in homelessness is easy to see across Australia, with more rough sleepers on streets and tent cities in parks. But there's a group experiencing homelessness who prefer to go unnoticed — the growing number of people living in vehicles.

title.children: 'I don't get to relax, it's very scary': Thousands of people now live in cars. This is what it's like

image.altText: A woman in a brown shirt and floral skirt sits on some stairs with a typewriter

items.synopsis: When both people in a relationship are writers, creative space is a fault line. So are matters such as who looks after the kids, inspiration turf wars, and jealousy about success. Still, it's often the wives who ultimately choose writing over wedded bliss, writes Kerrie Davies.

title.children: Two writers, two careers, one relationship: Inside the literary couples where books were a battlefield

image.altText: Rows and rows of cylinders in cages sit on tarmac. In the background are excavators, trees and water tanks

items.synopsis: This toxic waste dump in Victoria contained everything from PFAS to asbestos — and even cash and a dog wrapped in a mattress — buried in 32 locations, some the size of AFL fields. Now $40 million later, the clean-up is almost complete.

title.children: Inside the massive clean-up of this giant, secret and highly toxic dump — and how it changed recycling for good

image.altText: Man makes a coffee at a machine in a cafe.

items.synopsis: Hospitality businesses are raising prices, reducing trading hours and considering scrapping loyalty perks as they struggle to cope with cost of living pressures.

title.children: Paying more for coffee lately? Cafes warn prices will keep rising in 'vicious cycle'

image.altText: Silhouetted figure of a woman to the left, farm gate to the right. Sunset in the centre

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal there is a court battle to keep a man who abducted and raped a German backpacker 10 years ago behind bars, with forensic psychiatrists fearing he was a high risk of reoffending.

title.children: A German backpacker responded to an ad to nanny in remote Queensland. It was a sex offender's trap

image.altText: Security personnel keep watch outside the Wuhan Institute of Virology during the visit by the World Health Organisation.

items.synopsis: US intelligence report on COVID-19 origins rejects some points raised by lab leak theory proponents.

title.children: No direct evidence COVID started in Wuhan lab, US report finds

image.altText: Nurses and doctor pictured during medical procedure, generic image.

items.synopsis: The controversial tool has been implemented in Auckland, taking a person's ethnicity into account when placing them on non-urgent surgery waitlists.

title.children: Ethnicity criteria to rank patients for surgery in New Zealand labelled 'a courageous move'

image.altText: Creekbed and road overflowing with water outside a house

items.synopsis: A rainband stretching more than 3,000 kilometres will engulf Australia next week, delivering soaking rains from the Pilbara and Kimberley, across the outback to the eastern seaboard.

title.children: Week-long drenching forecast across Australia as El Niño takes a rain check

image.altText: Xavier Coates and Jonah Pezet celebrate a Melbourne Storm try as Manly Sea Eagles' Reuben Garrick is on the ground.

items.synopsis: Cameron Munster cannot back up after State of Origin, but young five-eighth Jonah Pezet shows some brilliance of his own as the Melbourne Storm finish strong against the Sea Eagles.

title.children: Munster's replacement has two moments of brilliance late in Storm's win over Manly

image.altText: Errol Gulden runs off in celebration as Eagles players look on behind him

items.synopsis: Sydney pile the pain on the hapless West Coast Eagles, who suffer a club-record 171-point loss at the SCG, while Fremantle steady the ship with a crucial 32-point win over Essendon.

title.children: Swans crack 200 to hand Eagles record loss, Freo fire back with win over Bombers

image.altText: Female hands holding a mobile phone with a dark background.

items.synopsis: A man has helped police track his allegedly stolen ute using a phone app before the driver crashed into a patrol vehicle in the Adelaide Hills.

title.children: Phone app tracks stolen ute as police swoop on alleged thieves

image.altText: A large crocodile resting in the sun on a muddy bank

items.synopsis: A local clean-up group says it is prohibited from removing unmarked pots due to regulations. The matter has come to a head again after a juvenile crocodile was found dead in an unmarked crab pot on the bank of a river in north Queensland.

title.children: Community frustrated after juvenile crocodile drowns while caught in old fishing pot

image.altText: A woman holds a bucket of oyster shells in front of the Opera House.

items.synopsis: An Indigenous artist enlists the public's help to clean tens of thousands of oyster shells for a new sculpture reminding visitors of Bennelong Point/Tubowgule's cultural significance.

title.children: Indigenous artist recreates midden at Sydney's Opera House with help of 'scrub club'

image.altText: Woman with hair pulled back, wearing funky black glasses and a green jumper smiles slightly at camera

items.synopsis: Lily Foster battled addiction for 20 years and "lost" everything. She wants to share her "lived experience" so others can benefit but in Tasmania, it's not easy for her to make her voice heard.

title.children: 'I lost everything to addiction': Lily wants to share what she's learned to help others

image.altText: a picture of one of the Bays on Magnetic Island and surrounding rainforest

items.synopsis: The 26-year-old tourist had celebrated her birthday just last week, according to her employer.

title.children: 'She was a great friend': Belgian tourist dies after motor-scooter crash on island off Queensland coast

image.altText: An Australian female professional golfer watches the progress of a shot down the fairway.

items.synopsis: West Australian Minjee Lee makes her move on the leaderboard at the Women's PGA Championship as she tries to claim her third major.

title.children: Lee rockets up the leaderboard as she looks to claim third major in three years

image.altText: Steven Schwartz pictured outside court with a mobile phone and paper work in his hands.

items.synopsis: The US lawyer, a colleague and their Manhattan law firm were fined for submitting fake citations in a court filing.

title.children: 'Use with caution': How ChatGPT landed this US lawyer and his firm in hot water

image.altText: Palestinians take cover during an Israeli raid in Jenin.

items.synopsis: The United Nations human rights high commissioner says conflict in the West Bank is deteriorating sharply, calling on Israel to reset its policies and comply with international law.

title.children: UN calls out Israel for 'use of advanced military weaponry' in deadly West Bank clashes

image.altText: A submersible under sea with air bubbles coming out from the top.

items.synopsis: OceanGate co-founder Guillermo Sohnlein defends the company's deceased CEO against claims he dismissed safety warnings, as officials work to decide who will investigate the disaster.

title.children: 'Keenly aware of the risks': OceanGate co-founder defends dead CEO's approach to safety as probe launched

image.altText: A wasp on a tree.

items.synopsis: Scientists find a new biocontrol measure to fight the destructive Sirex wasp, that attacks the softwood pine trees we rely on to build our homes and furniture.

title.children: Parasitic roundworm discovery boosts biological battle against tree-killing wasp

image.altText: A man with dark hair and a moustache stands on a beach with his two young daughters

items.synopsis: Residents rail against a Perth council's proposal to install more than a dozen groynes along a 5-kilometre stretch of beach to prevent a receding coastline from wiping out roads or even homes.

title.children: Locals unite to reject groyne plan to save Perth's northern beaches

image.altText: Two women standing and not looking at each other with view of skyline, mountains and clouds in the background.

items.synopsis: Australian politics is facing a sexual harassment reckoning. Thanks to a crucial scene in a Netflix political drama, so is Taiwan. How did the show Wave Makers become a rallying cry for Taiwan's MeToo movement, and why has it taken so long for people to come forward with allegations of sexual harassment?

title.children: What does 'eating tofu' have to do with Taiwan's rising #MeToo movement?
